summary.p: Breviary Fragment of readings and propers for June 29 to July 3:
Lines 1r-16r, Feast of Sts. Peter and Paul, Apostles (June 29);
Lines 16r-24r, Octave of St. John the Baptist (July 1);
Lines 24r-28v, Feast of Sts. Processus and Martinian (July 2);
Lines 28v-29v, Translation of St. Martin, Bishop and Feast of St. Menas, Martyr (July 3).

msItem.incipit:
A quote from "Sermo CCXCVIII" by Augustine of Hippo:
"solui non uult. Ille tamen qui dicebat concupiscentiam habens dissolui et esse cum Christo."
Source: Natali apostolorum Petri et Pauli, IV, Caput III. Patrologia Latina. Volume 38.
"Est enim quoddam dulce vinculum corporis, et ligatus est homo, et solvi non vult. Ille tamen qui dicebat, Concupiscentiam habens dissolvi, et esse cum Christo, gratulabatur quod ista vincula essent aliquando solvenda."

condition.p: The folium appears free of damage from rodents, insects, and fire, but some small staining can be seen, particularly in the bottom margin. The parchment shows variation in color throughout, including the stains, but a clearly rectangular segment in the lower right of the verso (covering about 4/5 of the text) is lighter in color than the surrounding parchment. This suggests either that this rectangular segment received a different amount of exposure to light than the rest of the parchment over a sustained period of time or that binding glue was applied to the parchment surrounding the rectangle. The parchment appears likely to have been trimmed from its original size, since the top and outer margins are smaller than might be expected. Fold lines are not apparent. A pin-prick sized hole is on the outer margin of the second line from the top.
condition.damage: Smudges of blank ink are evident in a few places: between 'qui' and 'item' (r. line 12), above 'quodlibet' (r. line 12), on 'gloriam' (r. line 15), above 'estis' (v. line 9), and above 'christiani' (v. line 13).

layout.p: 1 leaf; 29 lines per side; Ruled with hard point, with two parallel vertical lines bounding the text on both right and left margins.

The layout of the text is instrumental to its meaning and function. In addition to the capitals, abbreviations, and script sizes, intentional spacing contributes visually to delineate segments of the text. Some capitals jut into the margin to signal textual shifts.
Two rubricated notations also stand in the left margin of the verso: "ii" before v. line 6 and "iii" before v. line 25.

handNote.p: Written in Carolingian miniscule with ovoid and compressed characteristics of Protogothic or Pre-Gothic.

Scripts of various size are used to distinguish between various parts of the breviary. For example, passages for readings are larger than the instructions for chant (as in the shift from larger to smaller script between virtutum and si in r. line 4) and titles of antiphons or versicles may be smaller than liturgical directions (as in the shift from smaller to larger script between vobis and excepta in r. line 10). Headings are in red (Processi et Martiniani Capitulum, r. line 24). Notation for the hours of the office are inconsistently rubricated; rubricated examples include ad primum and ad tertiam (r. line 22), whereas ad uesperos et matutinum (r. line 12) is written in the brown ink of the text.

The aspect of the script is vertical, with straight upright strokes and round bows; n, m, and u similarly have vertical minims and rounded connections. Ascenders and descenders do not extend far beyond the text-line, resulting in a neat and nearly square line of text with a small ratio between the minims and the ascenders. Ascenders, such as for l and d exhibit spatulate and forked tops. Initial I may rest on the text line, as in Iterum (v. line 18) with a tall ascender; alternatively, initial I may curve below the text line as in Ille (r. line 1; v. line 16), particularly in order to distinguish between I and the double ll.

Morphology of note includes the following: vertical Uncial a has a round bow with only a slight hook curving above; d is seen in both vertical and uncial varieties (even within the same word, as in dedi in r. line 18); f typically rests on the line; g is drawn with a relatively vertical descender that rounds gracefully with an open bow below the text line; round r, capital r, and r with hooked shoulder are used; round and long s are both used, with round s typically reserved for initials, abbreviations, and the end of words; x looks like a tiny j conjoined with c; y sports a decorative dot between its arms.

Orthography: This manuscript displays a consistent habit of using e in place of ae in many words. For example, eternarum for aeternarum (r. line 4) and cetere for ceterae (r. line 8). This orthographic habit seems to be at work in the hymn title Oliv[a]e bin[a]e (r. line 11). Also, the use of c in place of t is remarkable, as in tercium (r. line 7), Exspectacio (r. line 25), and preciosis (v. line 25). However, the reader will remark agnitionem (r. line 14). Contempnere with a p (v. line 20) is of note.

Abbreviations include the following: nomina sacra (for example, Christo r. line 2); common abbreviations for pro, prae, and post; interesting "cross bar" abbreviation for per, which does not truly cross the descender but rather consists of a rightward stroke from the descender; a superscript bar for final m or n (or for en in the case of tamen in r. line 1); superscript “oc” a or "open a" as in aliquando (r. line 2) and Priusquam (r. line 17); backward c or curved 9-shape for final us, as in ambobus (r. line 6); superscript elaborate 2-shape for ur as in nocturnos (r. line 4) and canatur (r. line 7); round r with a crossed tail following o for -orum as in membrorum (r. line 3). An abbreviation for lectione(m) is formed by an l with upward-reaching, diagonal branches on each side. This is used both alone (r. line 11) and in combination with other letters, as in dilectione (r. line 10). Psalmos (r. line 9) is abbreviated with a capital P with superscript sos, and feriales immediately after abbreviates the final es with a curved stroke extending from the l. Nostris (r. line 24) boasts an interesting morphology: abbreviating the internal ostr of the word is an r whose minim descends below the text line and sprouts a horizontal seat with two chair legs.
Single initials are used to abbreviate words that would have been easily intuited by the users of this breviary (usually, the second or third word in the title of an antiphon or hymn). In these cases, such as with terram (r. line 8), iugum (r. line 9), and mundi (r. line 10), the single-letter initial is both preceded and followed by a punctus. Ligatures include the following: ct ligature as in octavo (r. line 19); st ligature as in tribuisti (r. line 15); IN ligature (r. line 19).

Punctuation: The manuscript uses punctus, punctus elevatus, and punctus interrogativus. Punctus are used to mark off numbers in roman numerals and one-initial abbreviations for words. Three small clusters of neumes grace lines 17, 18, and 22 of the recto.

Decoration: Initial letters are decorated with red and black penwork. Red shading fills the internal spaces of the black initials, such as the bottom and top bows of capital B (Beati, r. line 5), the space above and below the bar on H (Hoc, r. line 7), and the space under the top stroke of T (Tollite, r. line 9). Initial letters also display decorative serifs on each stroke (except for capital O and for capital G, whose bar is a continued curve from the body). Often, the curved or straight serifs end in a tight roll or dot. Capital E (as in Expectacio, r. line 25) and Uncial E (as in Eodem, v. line 6) are both used. In a few places (as within the concave spaces of the curved S in Si, r. line 4, and of the C in Cotidie, r. line 9), smaller capitals penned in the normal brown ink of the text also receive rubricated decoration.

Marginalia: Five faded additional lines of marginalia on the bottom of the verso (v. lines 30-34) includes three prayers. The script is different from that of the breviary’s text. Noticeably, g as in suffragantibus (v. line 32) has a flat top with a descender extending from the left of the top stroke and curving down, then right, and back around, similar to an Arabic numeral 5. Also, a has a smaller, more thorn-like bow with a longer, more curved arch above; the final descender of m curves below the letter in some places (as in martini); some letters appear more square as in the boxy “round s” and square p, whereas the shaft of t is more curved; r has a more open aspect, appearing similar to a modern v, and lacking the characteristic sharp hook of the breviary’s script. The superscript bar in the marginalia is curved on both sides, creating an elongated sideways s shape, whereas the superscript bar in the breviary’s text is flat with an upward stroke on the right. Abbreviations in the marginalia include nomina sacra; common abbreviations for per, pro, and prae; 9-shape for -us; superscript abbreviations for -er (s-shape) and -ur (infinity shape); and qs with superscript bar for quaesumus. The final Per [Dominum...] punctuates the prayers with an enlarged abbreviation evocative of a cross.

decoNote.p: Red capitals are used throughout for annotations and section divisions. Of particular note is the two-line-high, rubricated initial T (r. line 28). It is concave on both ends of the top stroke and on the foot, which has a small decorative pen trail.

Black capitals decorated with red ink are also used. Several black capital letters are found in multiple scripts. Compare the enlarged yet "lower case" black h (r. line 25) with the black Capital H above it (r. line 7).
A few capitals letters in the main brown ink of the text are also decorated with gracenotes of red ink. (See for example, 'In' r. line 8, 'Cotidie' r. line 9, and 'In' r. line 23).

projectDesc.p:
The aims of this born-digital edition are twofold:
First, by providing both a diplomatic and interpretive edition, between which the viewer can toggle, this digital edition seeks to aid scholars and students of paleography in identifying and investigating the morphology, intention, and meaning of medieval abbreviations.
Second, by providing copious references for the liturgical elements of this breviary fragment, such as chants in the Cantus index, scriptural allusions, and comperable breviary fragments, this digital edition also seeks to aid scholars of medieval liturgy in developing more robust understandings of liturgical culture and ritual.
Editorial decisions in the transcription stage are described below. For more technical information on the processes of encoding manuscript features, please see the project website.

correction.p:
Abbreviations:
Two liturgical abbreviations have been preserved in the transcription. These are à (antiphon) & R (Responsorium).
Effort has been made to represent the morphology of medieval abbreviations present in the text, so as to aid students of paleography in recognizing the correspondence between the shape of the abbreviation and its signification. However, discretion has been applied to cases where the intended designation of the abbreviation seems more important than the individual instance of morphology. For example, in r. 22, superscript 'a' is used above i rather than a superscript tilda (~) in order to designate that the scribe's intention seems to have been the use of "a" as an ending for "primam."

Orthography:
Original spellings (such as supplementing c for t) have been preserved in the diplomatic edition and have been occasionally regularized in the interpretive edition (for example, 'Olivae binae' in r. line 11).

normalization.p:
Letterform:
Long 's' is transcribed as round 's' throughout.
The original form of u/v is preserved in the transcription except when abbreviations are expanded or original spellings are regularized. For example, when the abbreviated word 'uoƀ' is expanded to 'vobis' for the interpretive edition, the change from u to v is made.
The original use of i for j is preserved throughout the transcription (including Ihesus and Iohannes.
Effort has been made to preserve the original form of capitalized and small-form letters, despite letter size, including proper names.

Puncutation:
The medieval puncutation marks have been preserved in both diplomatic and interpretive editions. No effort has been made to translate these according to signficance into modern punctuation. For interpretive assistance, see Coulson, "Punctuation."
Punctus Elevatus (with onset) is transcribed as "!"
Punctus Interrogativus is transcribed as "?"
Punctus is transcribed as "."

segmentation.p: In the manuscript, the various liturgical elements, such as readings, chant titles, prayers, etc., are distinguished not only by rubricated abbreviations and decorated capital letters, but also by variation in the size of the text. These shifts in text size have not been preserved in the transcription; thus, the reader will need to observe them by referencing the facsimile provided.
Refrences to chants (antiphons, hymns, responsories, and verses) are given by the CAO number drawn from Hesbert's Corpus Antiphonalium Officii), which allows them to be located in the Cantus Index.

hyphenation.p: The original word division of the manuscript has been observed in both the diplomatic and interpretive transcription.

When the phrase denoting a liturgical element spans a line break, the reference to a chant is given in the beginning of the phrase whereas the reference to scriptural passages or to comparative sources are provided at the end of the phrase.

div.p: Rubenstein Latin MS 005 is a one-folium (i.e., one-leaf) fragment from a breviary, which is the “principal manuscript for the performance of the [Divine] Office throughout the year" (Clemens and Graham, 193). This fragment contains readings, prayers, and liturgical directions, which are all marked off by rubrication and shifts in font size.

This breviary example contains readings and propers for June 29 to July 3. Because fragmentary, the contents of this folium pick up in the middle of the readings for the feast day of St. Peter and St. Paul and end at the beginning of the directions for the celebration of the translation of St. Martin. In other words, the directions and readings for the first and fourth lessons on this fragment are incomplete.

[Marginalia:The five faded additional lines of marginalia on the bottom of the verso, comprising three prayers, are written in a different hand. The script is different from that of the breviary’s text. Noticeably, g as in suffragantibus (v. line 32) has a flat top with a descender extending from the left of the top stroke and curving down, then right, and back around, similar to an Arabic numeral 5. Also, a has a smaller, more thorn-like bow with a longer, more curved arch above; the final descender of m curves below the letter in some places (as in martini); some letters appear more square as in the boxy “round s” and square p, whereas the shaft of t is more curved; r has a more open aspect, appearing similar to a modern v, and lacking the characteristic sharp hook of the breviary’s script. The superscript bar in the marginalia is curved on both sides, creating an elongated sideways s shape, whereas the superscript bar in the breviary’s text is flat with an upward stroke on the right. Abbreviations in the marginalia include nomina sacra; common abbreviations for per, pro, and prae; 9-shape for -us; superscript abbreviations for -er (s-shape) and -ur (infinity shape); and qs with superscript bar for quaesumus. The final Per [Dominum...] punctuates the prayers with an enlarged abbreviation evocative of a cross. Please see the project website for a transcription of the marginalia with notes.]
